message_1: A certain amount of radioactive material has a half-life of 10 days. If there are 100 grams of this material initially, how much will be left after 30 days?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Final amount = Initial amount * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial amount is 100 grams, the half-life is 10 days, and the time elapsed is 30 days. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final amount = 100 * (1/2)^(30 / 10)
Final amount = 100 * (1/2)^3
Final amount = 100 * (1/8)
Final amount = 12.5 grams

So, after 30 days, there will be 12.5 grams of the radioactive material left.
